text: How can you do it, can you help me

Hey guys. Running into issues taking a website live with Google domains. I cannot get the root domain to forward. Does anyone have any experience with this? HubSpot does not provide instructions for Google Domains.
<@U7SL518D6> You might be able to chime in on this.

I haven’t found a great solution myself on this to be honest.

But what I know you can do is use cloudflare with page rules to solve this issue <https://support.cloudflare.com/hc/en-us/articles/200172286-How-do-I-perform-URL-forwarding-or-redirects-with-Cloudflare->
If you have a reason you don’t want to move your DNS to cloudflare, that’s where I’m not sure the best solution.
Thank you guys very much. I'm not sure what I did but it appears to resolved properly. Appreciate your insight

Hi everyone, is there any way to just upload a CSV of blog posts into HubSpot? We're not migrating from wordpress, have everything as a CSV, and backing into valid XML for the import parser is proving to be a hassle. I know <@U6W3H6YN8> has a repo to do this, but I was hoping a more straight forward solution might be out there. Thanks!
Follow up here. Using the synthetic records in the DNS to set up @ and point it to www seems to have worked.
just in case you guys run into this again
Can someone point me in the right direction for a tutorial/guide for submitting forms using react?

Hey folks! Here is a fun lil' redirect question:

I have recently archived and replaced a blog using dynamic pages generated by hubDB. The hubDB pages now live at what was the original blog versions URL and the blog version now lives at a different URL. The following redirect was dynamically generated when we changed the url within the blog settings. After that got all set up correctly we successfully published the DB version with original url and it happily points to the listings page that is generated dynamically using DB. yay!

```https?://www.domain.com/slug(?P<page_slug>/.*)?$
<http://www.domain.com/slug-archive{page_slug}>```

However, we are needing to make sure that anybody that goes to `<http://www.domain.com/slug-archive{page-slug}>` get's redirected to the new happy version that lives at `<https://www.domain.com/slug{page-slug}>` .... which was the original URL of all the pages to begin with.

We are concerned about creating a redirect loop with setting up a new redirect pointing from `/slug-archive{page-slug}` to `/slug{page-slug}` and I'm wanting to know if that concern is legit, and if so, could I get some advice on how to handle?
